Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[A11y]The Keyboard focus is not visible on selected item from the table." (#7881) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1063683
Repro Steps:
1. Hit the URL:https://www.nuget.org/
2. Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
3. Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
4. Search for a key term (say “json”) from search box.
5. Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
6. Navigate to "Version History" control and hit enter.
7. Turn on high contrast.
8.Check if in high contrast the row that is selected(highlighted),the same highlighted row is also visible in high contrast while navigating using Tab key.

Actual:
The keyboard focus on selected item from the table is not clearly visible in high contrast black/white mode.

Similar issue have been observed in below scenarios : 
1).Json ->OwnerSection
Repro Steps:
1. Hit the URL:https://www.nuget.org/
2. Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
3. Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
4. Search for a key term (say “json”) from search box.
5. Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
6. Navigate to "Owners" section present on bottom right of the screen.
7. Check if the image of "newtonsoft" is visible in high contrast black mode.
1063683_A11y_[BM]NuGetService_OwnerSection_HighContrast.PNGBug_1063683_A11y_[BM]NuGetService_OwnerSection_HighContrast.PNG

Expected:
The focus on the selected item from the table should be clearly visible in high contrast mode.

Notes:
I was actually unable to reproduce case 1 at all. The table highlights keyboard focus correctly without issue. The only possible issue is that the light blue that indicates which version page we are on is not visible in high contrast.
For case 2, I'm not sure what action we are expected to take for static images; I'm not sure we can be expected to apply high contrast settings to static images.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Increase package size limit/and or support LZMA" (#8042) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I am trying to package TensorFlow binaries, but the uncompressed size of a single 2.x GPU binary is 1.3GB. ZIP+Deflate-compressed is ~400MB. XZ+LZMA2-compressed is ~100MB, but NuGet does not support LZMA2 compression, meaning unpacking needs installation scripts, which are no longer supported.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Overall, I think supporting LZMA2 or even just ZIP+LZMA would be the best solution, but the client team already closed that issue for whatever reason https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/890 . So as an alternative for my scenario it would be sufficient to up the limit to 500MB, or better 750MB to be future-proof.

### Additional context
N/A

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "SHA value in Http header for Package metadata response" (#8048) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
While looking into [this](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8352) performance bug I noticed we're wasting so much time just downloading json and deserializing it. Some of those files are 300-400MB size for MS some internal projects. We need some way to know just content changed or not without having to download whole json response.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I want to have SHA signaturen property of Package metadata response header. So that way we don't have download large json unless there are change of content. Currently we're just keep downloading same giant json and saving into cache file for a day or several hours then keep downloading same thing, which is very costly.
For example I got this response during debug I just want to add sha signature of Json body.
Response:
`
{Pragma: no-cache
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Vary: Accept-Encoding

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Question about license file" (#8035) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I have a general question about the license for a Nuget package.

Let's assume that a Nuget package is made available under "The MIT License" that is used by an application. We intend on distributing the application (or even using the application internally).

Now according to the terms of MIT License, we must include the license file along with the application binaries we distribute. Here's what is general verbiage of this license:

> The MIT License (MIT)
> 
> Copyright © 2020 <copyright holders>
> 
> Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of this software and associated documentation files (the “Software”), to deal in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:
> 
> **The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all copies or substantial portions of the Software**.
> 
> THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED “AS IS”, WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN THE SOFTWARE.
> 

So far so good.

However what I am observing is that there is no consistency in the inclusion of license file with the Nuget package. Some packages include them (e.g. NewtonSoft.JSON) while some don't.

Reading the specification of [`nuspec`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec) and especially the [`license`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec#license) section, I am led to believe that the license file is embedded with the `nupkg` file. However some of the packages I inspected, I found that's not the case. I changed the extension of package file (from nupkg to zip) and unzipped the file but could not find the license file in there.

Furthermore, when we install the packages what does in the `bin` directory of the application (and eventually made to the application package) are just the binary files (dlls etc.) and not the license file.

I am wondering how folks are dealing with this situation? 

Are they manually downloading the license file and including it as part of application so that the license file finds it way to the bin directory of the application? Or is there something else that is being done to stay compliant with the MIT license?

Any thoughts on this would be highly appreciated.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Download count decreased for the VaultSharp package" (#7986) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Bug Description
The download count for the VaultSharp package decreased in the last week, from 821,000 odd to 789,000 odd.

### To Reproduce
1. On this URL https://www.nuget.org/packages/VaultSharp/ see the download count. 

### Expected behavior
Download count should be around 821,000 odd. I don't have a screenshot for it, but that was the count 2 days ago. The download count it shows is 789,000 odd. 

### Additional context
It seems like the count got reset to a value that belonged to last week. The reduced number seems very familiar.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Stop packing UI projects" (#9678) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/1840 started packing:

NuGet.PackageManagement.UI
NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio
NuGet.VisualStudio.Common
NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.TestContract

The PR says it was for some perf infrastructure, but we don't we it.

If we stop packing these projects we will save time by not packing a few nupkgs, not signing those nupkgs, not needing time to upload those nupkgs, storage savings from not archiving or publishing these nupkgs. Finally, it will be obvious we won't need to maintain API compatability when we start using Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PublicApiAnalyzers.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to pack language specific custom license file" (#9680) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

We have library which is targeting Net Standard 2.1, As PackageLicenseUrl tag is deprecated, we have to pack license file in text format.

Now my simple question is- how can we pack license file different locale, so that When Nuget package gets installed it will open License file for respective Locale.. 
For example: If system locale is spanish, while installing Nuget package it should open spanish license file..
Currently we are using below tag to specify license file.
`<PackageLicenseFile>Lic_en.txt</PackageLicenseFile>`

Then we bundle like below:
`<None Include="..\Licenses\IBM.EntityFrameworkCore\Lic_en.txt" Pack="true" PackagePath="Lic_en.txt"/>`


Thanks,
Archana

2. Install NuGet: \\ddfiles\Drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\ dev-donnie-msft-pmuiTabSwitchUIFiltering\5.7.0.11466\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix 
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Install a clean machine with OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-RS5. 
2. Install Visual Studio 2019 Preview Master\30214.25. 
3. Install NuGet Client dev-donnie-msft-pmuiTabSwitchUIFiltering\5.7.0.11466. 
4. Launch Visual Studio 2019 Preview and try to open PMC & PM UI.
## Expected
PMC & PM UI can be opened successfully. 
## Actual
PMC & PM UI were disappeared after installing NuGet Client dev-donnie-msft-pmuiTabSwitchUIFiltering\5.7.0.11466. 
## Notes
1. The implicit NuGet Client is 5.7.0.6630 instead of 5.70.11466 after installing “NuGet Build tools” through “Quick Query”. 
2. It didn’t repro before installing NuGet Client dev-donnie-msft-pmuiTabSwitchUIFiltering\5.7.0.11466.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Stop packing UI projects" (#9678) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/1840 started packing:

NuGet.PackageManagement.UI
NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio
NuGet.VisualStudio.Common
NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.TestContract

The PR says it was for some perf infrastructure, but we don't we it.

If we stop packing these projects we will save time by not packing a few nupkgs, not signing those nupkgs, not needing time to upload those nupkgs, storage savings from not archiving or publishing these nupkgs. Finally, it will be obvious we won't need to maintain API compatability when we start using Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PublicApiAnalyzers.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
